p.content: This section considers qualitative adjectives, numbers and other quantifiers, articles, and demonstratives. The positions allowed for each of these elements within the nominal phrase will be dealt with in section

Qualitative adjectives express size, color, age, texture, form, or quality. This section is concerned with adjectives that modify nouns, in contrast to adjectives that acts as predicates, which will be covered in section

Qualitative adjectives express size, color, age, texture, form, or quality. One characteristic of this type of adjective is that more than one can modify a noun and in general the order of the adjectives can change (with a slight change in meaning due to the changes in scope of each adjective). For example,
versus
versus
This section is concerned with adjectives that modify nouns, in contrast to adjectives that acts as predicates. Predicate adjective constructions will be covered in section
Examples from
of the roots of qualitative adjectives are given in the following table. Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
Examples from
of qualitative adjectives are given in the following table:
Qualitative adjectives themselves may normally be modified. Some English examples are:
and

. Not all combinations of words work due to semantics and other considerations, but in general certain degree words and manner adverbs or manner adverb phrases can modify adjectives. Some languages have an affix on the adjective to intensify it, and other languages reduplicate the adjective.
In
, adjectives are not modified or intensified.
In
, adjectives may be modified by degree words which occur

Numbers come in two forms: cardinal numbers for counting and ordinal numbers that show position.

Numbers come in two forms: cardinal numbers for counting and ordinal numbers that show position. Numbers cannot be modified by the degree words like the qualitative adjectives and quantifiers can, though they usually occur in the same position as quantifiers. Cardinal numbers can, however, be modified by ordinal numbers and by
and
, as in
or
. Ordinal numbers and
and
can also modify nouns directly, as in
and
The basic forms for the cardinal numbers are given in the following table. Each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
The basic forms for the cardinal numbers are given in the following table:
Larger cardinal numbers can be compounds which may be written as independent words. Examples of compound numbers in
include:
Larger cardinal numbers can be compounds which may be written as independent words, such as
or
p.langData: six thousand one hundred and thirty three
p.content: . Examples of compound numbers in
include:
As seen in the examples above, the position of the ones digit and any conjunctions in
is

case.caseText: first or on the initial
last or in the final

p.content: part of the compound number.

Quantifiers can show up in various places in a nominal phrase based on their scope. Three types of quantifiers will be covered here, followed by partitive constructions.
Quantifiers can show up in various places in a nominal phrase based on their scope. Most languages have three sets of quantifiers besides numbers: wide scope quantifiers meaning
which modify the whole nominal phrase, quantifier determiners such as
or
, which do not co-occur with any other modifers except adjectives, and narrower scope quantifiers such as
or
. Each type will be considered in turn, and then partitive constructions will be covered.

section3.secTitle: Quantifiers which modify the whole nominal phrase

p.content: Quantifiers meaning
usually occur first (or last) in a nominal phrase, in a position distinct from the other quantifiers but in the same place as certain degree words or focus markers (see section
Quantifiers meaning
seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first (or last) in a nominal phrase, in a position distinct from the other quantifiers but in the same place as degree words like
and
(which can also act as focus markers, to be discussed in section
) and degree words like
and
(which can also co-occur with
). Some English examples are:
and
The following table shows how the wide scope quantifiers and degree elements which modify the whole nominal phrase are expressed in
. The forms shown in the table are the roots; each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
The following table shows how the wide scope quantifiers and degree elements which modify the whole nominal phrase are expressed in

text.content: , these are not expressed as independent words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach
Others are not expressed as independent words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they attach
as phrasal proclitics to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
as phrasal enclitics to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
as phrasal clitics either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
as prefixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
as suffixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
as either prefixes or suffixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either as clitics to the beginning or end of the nominal phrase, or as affixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

included in full nominal phrases are:

section3.secTitle: Quantifiers which do not co-occur with Determiners

p.content: The second set includes quantifiers like
and
which normally do not allow any other determiners such as articles, demonstratives or possessors in the nominal phrase.
The second set includes quantifiers like
and
which normally do not allow any other determiners such as articles, demonstratives or possessors in the nominal phrase. Some English examples of nominal phrases including these quantifiers are
and
p.langData: almost every little girl that I see
p.content: . Ungrammatical examples such as
and
illustrate that these quantifiers do not co-occur with articles, demonstratives or possessors. Note that an example like
is grammatical, but this is a case of
as the head of the nominal phrase, with a partitive phrase
modifying it, which will be covered in section

Others are not expressed as independent words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they attach
as phrasal proclitics to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
as phrasal enclitics to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
as phrasal clitics, either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
as prefixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
as suffixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
as either prefixes or suffixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either as clitics to the beginning or end of the nominal phrase, or as affixes to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

Other quantifiers occur within the nominal phrase showing their narrower scope. These quantifiers can normally be modified by degree words.
Other quantifiers, like
, and
, occur in a different position in the nominal phrase showing their narrower scope. In English, this is after an article, demonstrative or possessor and before an adjective and noun, as in
. Further, these quantifiers can normally be modified by degree words such as
and
, as in
or
has the following quantifiers of this type. The forms shown in the table are the roots; each one may surface with the apropriate classifier attached.
has the following quantifiers of this type:

Examples showing the degree affixes modifying a quantifier within a nominal phrase are:

All of the quantifiers, including numbers, can normally occur in partitive constructions, which are used to signify that one is talking about just a part of a larger group. Partitive constructions normally have a prepositional or postpositional phrase modifying the quantifier, which indicates the group or full item being discussed. Some languages may use a relative clause to express the group, instead of an adpositional phrase.
All of the quantifiers, including numbers, can normally occur in partitive constructions, which are used to signify that one is talking about just a part of a larger group. Examples include:
p.langData: just this much of the food
p.content: and

. As the examples show, partitive constructions of this type normally have a prepositional or postpositional phrase modifying the quantifier, which indicates the group or full item being discussed. Some languages may use a relative clause to express the group of the partitive construction instead of an adpositional phrase.
In

case.caseText: a relative clause is used instead of a prepositional a postpositional an adpositional an adpositional phrase to express the group.
another means than either an adpostional phrase or a relative clause is used to express the partitive meaning.

a prepositional a postpositional an adpositional an adpositional phrase which occurs before after on either side of ______ the quantifier expresses the group. The special prepositions postpositions prepositions or postpositions prepositions or postpositions used in partitive phrases are:

for the structure of relative clauses.
In English, the articles are
, and
. English demonstratives include
, and
. Some simple examples are:
p.langData: a book, an apple, the book, the books, this apple
p.content: and
Some languages only have one set, either articles or demonstratives. A few languages may not have either type expressed as independent words.

case.caseText: does not have either articles or demonstratives that are realized as independent words.
has only articles that are realized as independent words, no demonstratives.
has only demonstratives that are realized as independent words, no articles.
has both articles and demonstratives that are realized as independent words.
articles
demonstratives
articles and demonstratives
articles
demonstratives
articles and demonstratives

text.content: are marked with classifiers to agree with the noun. Just the roots are shown here; each one may surface with the appropriate classifier attached.

p.content: In

case.caseText: both the definite and indefinite articles are overt words.
only the definite article is overt; indefinite nouns are unmarked.
only the indefinite article is overt; definite nouns are unmarked.

p.content: Further, there

case.caseText: is only one set of articles which are used with both singular and plural nouns.
are separate forms of articles for singular and plural to agree with the noun.

p.content: The articles in
are:
Since

has a nominative-accusative case system, there are separate sets of articles to modify subjects and objects and possessors. The articles which can be used in subjects are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in direct objects are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in possessors are shown in the following table:
Since
has a ergative-absolutive case system, there are separate sets of articles to modify subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs
. The articles which can be used in subjects of transitive verbs are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in possessors are shown in the following table:
Since

has a split case system, there are separate sets of articles to modify subjects and objects and possessors, plus some additional sets for use under the special split ergativity conditions. The articles which can be used in subjects are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in direct objects are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in possessors are:
The articles which can be used in subjects of transitive verbs under the split ergativity conditions are shown in the following table:
The articles which can be used in subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs under the split ergativity conditions are:
There is another set of articles which can be used in
indirect objects, which are shown in the following table:

case.caseText: identical to the demonstrative pronouns
sometimes the same but sometimes distinct from the demonstrative pronouns
distinct from the demonstrative pronouns

The demonstratives in
are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstratives in
are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
Since

has a nominative-accusative case system, there are separate sets of demonstratives which can be used in subjects and objects and possessors. The demonstratives which can be used as subjects are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstratives which can be used in direct objects are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstratives which can be used in possessors are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
Since
has an ergative-absolutive case system, there are separate sets of demonstratives to use with subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs
. The demonstratives which can be used in subjects of transitive verbs are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used in subjects of intransitive verbs or in objects of transitive verbs are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used in possessors are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
Since

has a split case system, there are separate sets of demonstratives for the normal nominative-accusative case system, for use in subjects versus objects versus possessors, plus others for the special cases when the ergative-absolutive case system is used which modify subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs.
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used in subjects in the normal nominative-accusative system are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstratives which can be used in direct objects in the normal nominative-accusative system are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstratives which can be used in possessors are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstratives that can be used in subjects ot transitive verbs in the split ergativity situations are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:

The demonstratives which can be used in subjects of intransitive verbs or in objects of transitive verbs n the split ergativity situations are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
